xldoc.keywords: rbjones philosophy logic emotion reason romanticism

section.title: Overview
section.abstract: Positivism is traditionally both anti-dogmatic and dogmatic, in this similar to scepticism. In "liberal" positivism, we seek to capture the positive elements of positivism while discarding the negative dogmas.

section.title: Kolakowski's Conception of Positivism
section.abstract: Kolakowski identifies four key features of Positivism, we present them and point out the negative dogmatism.

sbcol.subsec: There is no real difference between 'essence' and 'phenomenon'.

"every abstract science is a method of abbreviating the recording of experiences and gives us no extra, independent knowledge in the sense that, via its abstractions, it opens access to empirically inaccessible domains of reality"

subsec.title: the denial that value judgements and normative statements can be knowledge

sbcol.subsec: An example of this is Hume's denial that one can derive an "ought" from an "is".
A belief in the essential unity of scientific method. Exactly in what that unity consists seems a bit variable.

section.title: Liberal Positivism
section.abstract: We recast the key features of Positivism eliminating the negative dogmatism.
